metadata.title: Effects of echinacea on the frequency of upper respiratory tract symptoms: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

abstract.original_text: Background: Upper respiratory tract infection symptoms are a common cause of morbidity. Herbal preparations of the plant Echinacea purpurea have immune-enhancing properties.

sentences.segment_text: Background : Upper respiratory tract infection symptoms are a common cause of morbidity .
Herbal preparations of the plant Echinacea purpurea have immune-enhancing properties .

abstract.original_text: Objective: To compare the frequency of upper respiratory tract symptoms in individuals receiving E purpurea capsules and those receiving placebo to evaluate the preventive efficacy of echinacea.

sentences.segment_text: Objective : To compare the frequency of upper respiratory tract symptoms in individuals receiving E purpurea capsules and those receiving placebo to evaluate the preventive efficacy of echinacea .

abstract.original_text: Methods: In a randomized, double-blind clinical trial, 90 volunteers recruited from hospital personnel were randomly assigned to receive 3 capsules twice daily of either placebo (parsley) or E purpurea for 8 weeks during the winter months. Upper respiratory tract symptoms were reported weekly during this period.

sentences.segment_text: double-blind clinical trial , 90 volunteers recruited from hospital personnel were randomly assigned to receive 3 capsules twice daily of either placebo ( parsley ) or E purpurea for 8 weeks during the winter months .

abstract.original_text: Results: Fifty-eight individuals were included in the final data analysis: 28 in the echinacea group and 30 in the placebo group. Individuals in the echinacea group reported 9 sick days per person during the 8-week period, whereas the placebo group reported 14 sick days (z ϭ Ϫ0.42; P ϭ .67). Mild adverse effects were noted by 8% of the echinacea group and 7% of the placebo group (P ϭ .24).

abstract.original_text: Conclusion: Prophylactic treatment with commercially available E purpurea capsules did not significantly alter the frequency of upper respiratory tract symptoms compared with placebo use.
